docs.lead_paragraph: As a reminder that the banking system is still a worrisome weak link in Mexico's robust economy, a newly created federal bank insurance agency has initiated two huge bailouts reminiscent of bank rescues of just a few years ago. The agency, the Bank Savings Protection Institute, decided on Thursday to take over Grupo Financiero Serfin S.A., Mexico's third-largest bank. Vicente Corta Fernandez, director of the agency, said it expected to have to put up at least $1.3 billion to save the bank, which declared that in practice it was bankrupt.

docs.lead_paragraph: Kaiser Permanente, one of the nation's largest health maintenance organizations, said yesterday that it was closing its money-losing Northeast division, at the end of the year. The move affects 575,000 members in four states, including 29,500 in the New York suburbs of Westchester County and Fairfield County in Connecticut. The H.M.O. said it lost almost $90 million on nearly $1 billion in revenue in the Northeast last year. Dr. David Lawrence, the chief executive of Kaiser Foundation Health Plans and Hospitals, said the company had decided against investing more money into the region.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Legislature's 1999 session reached its scheduled end today with all the usual frenzy but none of the results, as lawmakers failed to make deals on most unresolved issues, and girded for a showdown over whether the state would keep paying hospital bills after Sunday. Several Republican Senators and Senate aides said that on Thursday, the Senate's Republican majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, will, for the first time, allow his house to vote on a bill making it illegal for protesters to block access to an abortion clinic. The bill, which is almost assured of passage, would not go as far as the one passed by the Democrat-controlled Assembly, and it would include tougher criminal penalties for stalkers, which some Democrats dislike. But aides to Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said it would be seriously considered.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Expanding mental health coverage could, in the long run, reduce insurance costs rather than raise them, as Mark Schiller argues (Op-Ed, June 15). The high cost of unnecessary medical visits, tests and treatments related to anxiety, depression, stress and life's problems could be lowered if more people had the option of treatment for these mental health problems. Additionally, the high costs of addictions, dysfunctional families and other forms of acting out could be reduced if expanded mental health insurance were available to deal with these problems. PATRICIA GOLD New York, June 15, 1999 The writer is a psychotherapist.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Drug Switching Saves Money, but There Is a Cost'' (Week in Review, June 13): The health maintenance organizations should be pilloried for their depersonalization of the human condition. First, patients were deprived of their individuality when they were renamed ''covered lives.'' Then, doctors were stripped of their dedication and purpose when they were renamed ''providers.'' Now, the very personal choice of and need for certain medications is being manipulated to suit the H.M.O's bottom lines with the mendacious and sanitized term ''formulary management.''

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Regarding Mark Schiller's statement that it would be unwise to expand coverage for mental health because many businesses would be forced to drop all coverage (Op-Ed, June 15): It is already the case that smaller businesses cannot provide adequate health care coverage to their employees, whether for medical or psychiatric needs. Health care has become a commodity, and it is the larger corporations alone that have the resources to negotiate and buy wholesale health coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: By a vote of 99 to 0, the Senate today passed a bill that would expand Medicaid and Medicare so hundreds of thousands of people with disabilities could retain their health benefits when they return to work. The House is well on its way to passing similar legislation. President Clinton hailed today's vote and prodded Congress to finish work on the bill as quickly as possible.

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of people across Latin America are, for better or worse, getting a taste of American-style health insurance. Pushed by the rising expectations of a growing middle class, countries in the region are opening their government-dominated health systems to private companies, both domestic and foreign. Some of the biggest United States insurers, seeing Latin America as a prime growth market, are actively testing the waters from Mexico to Argentina, Brazil and Chile. Latin Americans already spend $120 billion annually on health care, or about $412 per capita, adjusted to reflect local health costs. While this is only about one-ninth of the total health spending in the United States, the big Latin American countries are spending a much bigger share of their economies on health than all the Asia-Pacific economies except Japan.
